newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - July 3.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - July 3.

text.p: The New York Times reported the following business stories Thursday:
* The stock market went higher as the Federal Reserve's decision to keep interests steady helped lift secondary indexes into record territory but left the Dow just short of a new high.
* General Motors said its sales fell 13.3 percent last month.
* In the months before a Johnson & Johnson unit removed a home HIV test fromthe market, Federal regulators issued directives to the company to clean up its quality control proceedures.
* Few companies say they have the vaguest idea what the Clinton administration's new limits on smog and on emissions of fine particles mean for their operations.
* Germany's troubled efforts to introduce digital televisiongot a lift as the main cable provider made peace with the two biggest entertainment companies.
* AT&T and Stet said they agreed to cooperate in Latin America and Europe.

* A judge overturned a ruling in the Dow Corning bankruptcy case that had threatened to derail negotiations by mandating a new committee to negotiate on behalf of women who claim injuries from the company's breast implants.
* British big business will have the lowest tax ceiling of any Western industrialized state after the new British government passed its first budget.
* Supporters of the proposed tobacco settlement said it could help bring about so-called safer cigarettes.
* Activity on advertising accounts is accelerating again.
* The Central Bank of Thailand's decision to devalue the currency represents a gamble by Thai policy makers to shore up the country's faltering economy.
* The black market is thriving in Italy's market for luxury goods.
* The federal reserve decided to leave interest rates unchanged.
* SBC Communications Inc sued the government seeking to overturn a large portion of the Telecommunications Act of 1996.
